Class Tile

java.lang.Object
javafx.scene.Node
javafx.scene.Parent
javafx.scene.layout.Region
javafx.scene.layout.Pane
javafx.scene.layout.StackPane
Tile
All Implemented Interfaces:
javafx.css.Styleable, javafx.event.EventTarget
public class Tile extends javafx.scene.layout.StackPane
Represents a Tile in a game of Minesweeper and all the actions it might happen to it, as well as every design it might change to.

  • Field Details

    • numBombs

      int numBombs
      number of bombs adjacent to a tile

    • flagged_count

      public static int flagged_count
      To check if the first four flags deployed on tiles, flagged the super bomb. If the super bomb is flagged within the first 4 attempts, the row and column where it is located is revealed.

    • count_flags

      public static int count_flags
      To constraint the number of flagged tiles. The number of flags must be the same as the number of bombs in the ongoing game.

    • leftClickSucesses

      public static int leftClickSucesses
      How many attempts to uncover tiles were successful in one game It has a typo, I know :). Also, neighbours and color, British and American versions of English are mixed in here. This variable is presented in the Rounds MenuItem.

    • hasBomb

      boolean hasBomb
      flag: does a tile contain a bomb?

    • isSuperBomb

      public boolean isSuperBomb
      flag: does this tile contain the super bomb?

    • active

      private boolean active
      flag: is this tile active or has it been disabled?

    • flagged

      private boolean flagged
      flag: is this tile flagged?

    • uncoveredTiles

      public static int uncoveredTiles
      count the tiles that have been uncovered to build the statement that when it is met, the player wins: (Total tiles) - (Uncovered tiles) = (Total bombs in the current game)

    • color

      javafx.scene.paint.Color color
      In Main.java, the color of every number of bombs adjacent to a tile is defined. Null is default in case of 0, which is not displayed. An empty tile is displayed instead.

    • btn

      javafx.scene.control.Button btn
      each tile is a button that can be clicked of flagged and then becomes disabled.

    • neighbours

      ArrayList<Tile> neighbours
      for the recursive reveal of neighbors in the case of a blank click (blank click is when we click a tile with no adjacent bombs)

    • flag

      static javafx.scene.image.Image flag
      Image for flagging tiles. Can be changed for different aesthetics.

  • Constructor Details

    • Tile

      Tile(int x, int y, boolean hasBomb)
      The Tile constructor constructs a Tile using its x and y coordinates, as well as the information for the existence or not of a bomb behind the Tile. It also defines the Tile's dimensions in the UI and sets that if the Tile receives a mouse click, the method onClick is called, because various actions can be taken from a mouse click, depending on the situation and the mouse click (if it is primary/left or not).

  • Method Details

    • onClick

      private void onClick(javafx.scene.input.MouseEvent e)
      onClick is a method that defines what will happen to the Tile when it is clicked. First of all, there is a clicking sound. Then, it examines if a primary/left or secondary/right click has been performed. If it is the former, we have the scenarios of it having a bomb, a blank tile or a simple tile. A blank tile would recursively reveal other tiles, as in the classical game. If it is the latter, we have the secondary click which flags the tiles. If a super bomb exists and if it is flagged within the first four tries the super bomb's column and row are revealed.

    • blankClick

      private void blankClick(Tile tile)
      blankClick is a method that recursively reveals adjacent tiles of a blank tile For each neighbor tile that is active, the method disables the corresponding button, removes any graphics from it, sets its text to the number of bombs around it, sets its text color to the corresponding color, and marks it as inactive. The uncoveredTiles variable is also incremented, keeping track of the number of uncovered tiles. If the neighbor tile has no bombs around it, the method recursively calls itself with the current neighbor tile as its argument. This means that the same process will be applied to all of the neighbor's neighboring tiles until all of the blank tiles and their adjacent non-blank tiles have been uncovered.
